rdf:Description.dc:title: Mary Newbury Adams letters, 1857-1869
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Adams, Mary Newbury, 1837-1901
rdf:Description.dc:description: Letters from Mary Newbury Adams (1837-1901) to her sister Frances and brother-in-law John. The letters contain a mixture of family and day-to-day news, with mentions of organizations in which Mary was active.
rdf:Description.dc:publisher: Iowa State University Library Special Collections and University Archives; http://archives.lib.iastate.edu/
rdf:Description.dc:relation:
Mary Newbury Adams letters, 1857-1869
Adams Family Papers, 1618-1976, undated, http://findingaids.lib.iastate.edu/spcl/manuscripts/MS010.html
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: Mary Newbury Adams (1837-1901), third child of Reverend and Mrs. Samuel Newbury, was born in Peru, Indiana. Her father was a firm believer in education for both sexes. When Mary was nineteen years of age, she was sent to Mrs. Willard's Female Seminary in Troy, New York, where she graduated in 1857. She married Austin Adams, a young lawyer and teacher, a few months later. Their home in Dubuque became an avant-garde salon for intellectuals of the period (1860's through 1880's). In 1866, Mrs. Adams became interested in women's suffrage and did much to promote it through writing and speaking. She was a member of the Association for Advancement of Women, the American Historical Association, vice chairperson of Women's Branch of the World's Congress Auxiliary of the Colombian Exposition, and numerous literary societies. Dubuque County (Iowa); Iowa (state)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mary Newbury Adams letters, 1870-1879
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Adams, Mary Newbury, 1837-1901
rdf:Description.dc:description: Letters from Mary Newbury Adams (1837-1901) to her sister Frances and brother-in-law John. The letters contain a mixture of family and day-to-day news, with mentions of organizations in which Mary was active.
rdf:Description.dc:publisher: Iowa State University Library Special Collections and University Archives; http://archives.lib.iastate.edu/
rdf:Description.dc:relation:
Mary Newbury Adams letters, 1870-1879
Adams Family Papers, 1618-1976, undated, http://findingaids.lib.iastate.edu/spcl/manuscripts/MS010.html
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: Mary Newbury Adams (1837-1901), third child of Reverend and Mrs. Samuel Newbury, was born in Peru, Indiana. Her father was a firm believer in education for both sexes. When Mary was nineteen years of age, she was sent to Mrs. Willard's Female Seminary in Troy, New York, where she graduated in 1857. She married Austin Adams, a young lawyer and teacher, a few months later. Their home in Dubuque became an avant-garde salon for intellectuals of the period (1860's through 1880's). In 1866, Mrs. Adams became interested in women's suffrage and did much to promote it through writing and speaking. She was a member of the Association for Advancement of Women, the American Historical Association, vice chairperson of Women's Branch of the World's Congress Auxiliary of the Colombian Exposition, and numerous literary societies. Dubuque County (Iowa); Iowa (state)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mary Newbury Adams letters, 1880-1881
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Adams, Mary Newbury, 1837-1901
rdf:Description.dc:description: Letters from Mary Newbury Adams (1837-1901) to her sister Frances and brother-in-law John. The letters contain a mixture of family and day-to-day news, with mentions of organizations in which Mary was active.
rdf:Description.dc:publisher: Iowa State University Library Special Collections and University Archives; http://archives.lib.iastate.edu/
rdf:Description.dc:relation:
Mary Newbury Adams letters, 1880-1881
Adams Family Papers, 1618-1976, undated, http://findingaids.lib.iastate.edu/spcl/manuscripts/MS010.html
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: Mary Newbury Adams (1837-1901), third child of Reverend and Mrs. Samuel Newbury, was born in Peru, Indiana. Her father was a firm believer in education for both sexes. When Mary was nineteen years of age, she was sent to Mrs. Willard's Female Seminary in Troy, New York, where she graduated in 1857. She married Austin Adams, a young lawyer and teacher, a few months later. Their home in Dubuque became an avant-garde salon for intellectuals of the period (1860's through 1880's). In 1866, Mrs. Adams became interested in women's suffrage and did much to promote it through writing and speaking. She was a member of the Association for Advancement of Women, the American Historical Association, vice chairperson of Women's Branch of the World's Congress Auxiliary of the Colombian Exposition, and numerous literary societies. Dubuque County (Iowa); Iowa (state)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mary Newbury Adams letters, 1861-1889
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Adams, Mary Newbury, 1837-1901
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mary Newbury Adams, 1837-1901; Women -- Iowa -- 19th century; Women -- Social life and customs -- 19th century; Women's rights -- United States; Women -- Suffrage -- United States; Feminists -- United States; Adams family; Women -- Societies and clubs -- Iowa Adams, Mary Newbury, 1837-1901; Newbury, Frances Elizabeth, 1833-1898; Whittier, John Greenleaf,1807-1892; Alcott, Amos Bronson, 1799-1888; Emerson, Ralph Waldo,1803-1882; Alcott, Louisa May, 1832-1888 1860s; 1880s
rdf:Description.dc:description: Letters from Mary Newbury Adams (1837-1901) to her sister Frances and brother-in-law John. The letters contain a mixture of family and day-to-day news, with mentions of organizations in which Mary was active.
rdf:Description.dc:publisher: Iowa State University Library Special Collections and University Archives; http://archives.lib.iastate.edu/
rdf:Description.dc:relation:
Mary Newbury Adams letters, 1861-1889
Adams Family Papers, 1618-1976, undated, http://findingaids.lib.iastate.edu/spcl/manuscripts/MS010.html
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: Mary Newbury Adams (1837-1901), third child of Reverend and Mrs. Samuel Newbury, was born in Peru, Indiana. Her father was a firm believer in education for both sexes. When Mary was nineteen years of age, she was sent to Mrs. Willard's Female Seminary in Troy, New York, where she graduated in 1857. She married Austin Adams, a young lawyer and teacher, a few months later. Their home in Dubuque became an avant-garde salon for intellectuals of the period (1860's through 1880's). In 1866, Mrs. Adams became interested in women's suffrage and did much to promote it through writing and speaking. She was a member of the Association for Advancement of Women, the American Historical Association, vice chairperson of Women's Branch of the World's Congress Auxiliary of the Colombian Exposition, and numerous literary societies. Dubuque County (Iowa); Iowa (state)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mary Newbury Adams letters, 1893-1901
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Adams, Mary Newbury, 1837-1901
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mary Newbury Adams, 1837-1901; Women -- Iowa -- 19th century; Women -- Social life and customs -- 19th century; Women's rights -- United States; Women -- Suffrage -- United States; Feminists -- United States; Adams family; Women -- Societies and clubs -- Iowa Adams, Mary Newbury, 1837-1901; Newbury, Frances Elizabeth, 1833-1898; Harrison, Hon. B. H. 1890s; 1900s
rdf:Description.dc:description: Letters from Mary Newbury Adams (1837-1901) to her sister Frances and brother-in-law John. The letters contain a mixture of family and day-to-day news, with mentions of organizations in which Mary was active.
rdf:Description.dc:publisher: Iowa State University Library Special Collections and University Archives; http://archives.lib.iastate.edu/
rdf:Description.dc:relation:
Mary Newbury Adams letters, 1893-1901
Adams Family Papers, 1618-1976, undated, http://findingaids.lib.iastate.edu/spcl/manuscripts/MS010.html
rdf:Description.dc:coverage: Mary Newbury Adams (1837-1901), third child of Reverend and Mrs. Samuel Newbury, was born in Peru, Indiana. Her father was a firm believer in education for both sexes. When Mary was nineteen years of age, she was sent to Mrs. Willard's Female Seminary in Troy, New York, where she graduated in 1857. She married Austin Adams, a young lawyer and teacher, a few months later. Their home in Dubuque became an avant-garde salon for intellectuals of the period (1860's through 1880's). In 1866, Mrs. Adams became interested in women's suffrage and did much to promote it through writing and speaking. She was a member of the Association for Advancement of Women, the American Historical Association, vice chairperson of Women's Branch of the World's Congress Auxiliary of the Colombian Exposition, and numerous literary societies. Dubuque County (Iowa); Iowa (state)
